Literature Review: The study of adsorption at nanoconfined solid–water interfaces has emerged as a critical area of research due to its implications in water treatment, catalysis, chemical separations, and environmental chemistry. The unique behavior of water and solutes under nanoconfinement challenges traditional models of interfacial reactivity, necessitating a reevaluation of our understanding of these processes. This literature review synthesizes recent experimental and theoretical advancements in the field, focusing on how nanoconfinement influences the physico-chemical properties of water and, consequently, the mechanisms of adsorption in nanopores. Nanoconfinement can manifest in various geometries, including pores/cages (3D confinement), channels (2D confinement), and slits (1D confinement), each altering the interfacial reactivity in distinct ways. Traditional measurements and models based on unconfined surfaces often fail to predict the chemical behaviors observed under these conditions. Recent studies have highlighted the significant impact of nanoconfinement on the structure and dynamics of water, which in turn dictate the energetics, pathways, and products of adsorption. For instance, the altered hydrogen bonding network and increased viscosity of nanoconfined water can lead to unexpected adsorption behaviors. Theoretical models incorporating these factors have begun to provide insights into the complex interplay between water structure and adsorption mechanisms. Furthermore, the role of surface complexation and speciation in nanoconfined environments has been a focus of recent research, revealing how these processes are influenced by the unique properties of nanoconfined water. The implications of these findings are vast, offering new avenues for the design of more efficient water treatment systems, catalysts, and chemical separation technologies. Future research directions include the development of more accurate computational models that can capture the nuances of nanoconfined systems, as well as experimental techniques that can probe these environments with greater precision. The continued exploration of adsorption at nanoconfined solid–water interfaces promises to deepen our understanding of these complex systems and unlock new possibilities for technological innovation.
